docs.snippet: The election of Francis is focusing scrutiny on his role at the Roman Catholic Church in Argentina, which was accused of complicity during a military junta’s violent reign.
docs.lead_paragraph: The election of Francis is focusing scrutiny on his role at the Roman Catholic Church in Argentina, which was accused of complicity during a military junta’s violent reign.
docs.abstract: Election of Francis as pope is focusing new scrutiny on his role in the Roman Catholic Church in Argentina, which has been accused of failing to resist--or even actively supporting--violent military dictatorship in the late 1970s; legacy presents challenge to Francis, who has repeatedly had to dispute claims that he allowed kidnapping of two priests in his order in 1976 at start of Argentina's so-called Dirty War.

headline.seo: Francis Begins Reign as Pope Amid Echoes of Argentina’s Dirty War
headline.main: Starting a Papacy, Amid Echoes of a ‘Dirty War’
headline.print_headline: Starting a Papacy, Amid Echoes of a ‘Dirty War’

docs.snippet: These days, when it comes to designing hotels and resorts in out-of-the-way places, less is more. Instead of historically inspired villas or clusters of vernacular-style huts or cottages, architects are embracing a kind of eco-modernism, with quietly...
docs.lead_paragraph:
These days, when it comes to designing hotels and resorts in out-of-the-way places, less is more. Instead of historically inspired villas or clusters of vernacular-style huts or cottages, architects are embracing a kind of eco-modernism, with quietly powerful structures that take their cues — literally — from the landscape. Rather than imposing themselves on their spectacular surroundings, these buildings become part of them, sometimes so much so that it’s hard to tell where the natural stops and the man-made begins.
 
 Hotel Fasano Las Piedras High above Punta del Este, Uruguay, the Brazilian architect Isay Weinfeld designed 32 concrete bungalows with rustic stone bases that seem to nestle naturally into their rocky hillside setting. The austerity of their exteriors contrasts with the warm, Brazilian Modernist vibe of the interiors.

docs.snippet: A reimagining of the 1981 horror classic “The Evil Dead” stirs mixed reactions from the original’s fans.
docs.lead_paragraph: A reimagining of the 1981 horror classic “The Evil Dead” stirs mixed reactions from the original’s fans.
docs.abstract: Fede Alvarez's big-budget remake of the seminal 1981 Sam Raimi horror classic The Evil Dead stirs mixed reactions from the original’s fans; Evil Dead was part of a wave of low-budget independent horror films in the late 1970s and early 1980s that used crude effects to tell gory tales, and is considered untouchable, even if the remake is getting good reviews.

headline.seo: Bruce Campbell Helps With a New ‘Evil Dead’

docs.snippet: SISLER--Donald Grant. Died peacefully from natural causes on March 4, 2013. He had just celebrated his 97th birthday with his family. He was born, reared and educated in Washington, DC. During WW II he was stationed at the United States embassies in...
docs.lead_paragraph: SISLER--Donald Grant. Died peacefully from natural causes on March 4, 2013. He had just celebrated his 97th birthday with his family. He was born, reared and educated in Washington, DC. During WW II he was stationed at the United States embassies in Santiago, Chile, and in Montevideo, Uruguay, where he became fluent in Spanish. In 1946 he joined Coca-Cola Export Corporation and was assigned to Germany as a Technical Observer. The following year he was transferred to Buenos Aires, Argentina, subsequently serving in Rio de Janeiro, Brazil, where he learned Portuguese, and then Lima, Peru, as manager of the Andean Region. In 1962 Don was elected a Vice President of The Coca-Cola Export Corporation. In 1967 he was appointed manager of the Western European Area and lived in Brussels, Belgium, then in Paris, France. He retired in 1976 to finally live in his favorite city, New York. Paris was his second favorite city where he owned an apartment on Avenue George V with a fabulous view of the Tour Eiffel. Soon after World War II, in July 1946, his only brother, Vincent Ambrose Sisler, who served as a submarine commander in the Pacific, was killed in an automobile accident, leaving three small daughters. Don was a loving, caring uncle to his nieces and their families throughout his life. He took great pleasure in showing his family, friends and visitors from abroad the wonders of New York City. He was a great supporter of the performing arts, especially the Metropolitan Opera, where he was an Advisory Director, and underwrote ten of its PBS telecasts. Putting on his tux and striding across Central Park from his home on 5th Ave to the Met was a great joy for him. He was a wonderful raconteur, with a terrific sense of humor and an infectious laugh. His joie de vivre set an example for his family and friends. Charming, kind and caring to everyone, he was a gentleman of the old school an extraordinary man who lived an extraordinary life. He is survived by his nieces, Anne Sisler Latta and Tonia Sisler, nephew Dr. Adrian Sherman, great-nephews Jeffrey Latta and Michael Jacobs, great-niece Katherine Jacobs, and great-great nephew, Holden Latta.

headline.main: Paid Notice: Deaths  SISLER, DONALD GRANT
